answers.answer: Maybe he had one or more little strokes or he could have alzheimers. But at 80 I think it's typical to act differently, my parents arent that old and theyre not the same anymore...just a couple of thoughts...

there can be many reasons for this has he had an overall check up blood work , also has he been checked for dementia,yes his  blood sugar should be watched very carefully, some people can be forgetful, and some, may be scared of dying, one never knows, until you walk in their shoes so to speak, he could also be lonely, many reasons I know many people at age 90 are moving and a lot sharper in their mind than some young person, yet some label them also i do not agree with catmagnet 80 is not typical,maybe he is the one that acts different, and his parents may be fine, Older people, and the mentally ill are dear to me, as i have workd with people of all ages mental and physical  some meds can cause this, and they can be any age take him to the dr and find out   good luck to all

question: My father has been doing strange things we think now for about the last 2 to 20 years!  He fabricates stories, adds to others, and has all of us siblings up in arms because he tells one that the other said unkind things about them that we didn't, or he just makes up something some of us are supposed to have done and tells everyone in our family one at a time.  He is never wrong; and gets pretty irritated if you correct him..some of us have harbored some pretty initense feelings against the other because of things he has said that have turned out to not be true.  His Mother was definitly an NPD; based on research we have done, and a sibling that I personally think has NPD...the difference in my father is that he is full of empathy it seems for all kinds of people, and has always been a rock when we go through sad times...he has had diabetes we think for like 20 years because by the time he was diagnosed, he already had full blown neuropathy.  Can the blood sugar levels, personality changes be dementia, or a personality disorder, or just radical signs of aging?  He will never tell these stories around our Mother and if he does, he will shush her if she says anything different.  I tend to think he knows what he is doing on some level, others think he is losing his memory.  He eats horribly; doesn't take care of himself as a diabetic, doesn't think he should have to and I wonder if the blood sugar levels which are 37 - 200 are causing havoc on his brain?
title: 80 yr old Father personality changes
